page.title: 06FARMING
page.content: There is a useful account of the history of farming in Crai Parish by David Lewis published in BRYCHEINIOG Vol IX,1963, which describes in some detail the farming practices used during the inter-war years and up to the time of publication of that article. The principal activity is livestock rearing with much greater emphasis on sheep than on cattle. During the last two decades there has been an even greater swing towards the production of fat lambs for the meat market. This results in part from the existence of E.E.C. sheepmeat subsidies and the generally poor prices for wool to be obtained from the Wool Marketing Board (which holds the monopoly to buy all wool produced by British farmers). Cattle are now only reared for beef. There are no milking herds left.
